Description: Terracotta cooking stove fragment. A pot-support: a theatre mask of Papposilenos or satyr with pointed ears, wild hair and a long striated beard, within a rectangular panel. The back is plain; part of the fire-bowl, with an everted rim, survives. The support and panel were made in a onepiece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a grey-brown core and many white inclusions; there is much burning on the beard, bowl and panel. Red slip.
Curator's comments: Ptolemaic parallel (Dunand 1990, no. 1005), second century BC parallel from Athribis (Myśliwiec and Abu Senna 1995, 226, fig. 25). Published (Şahin 2001, 120, fig. 120:Na 12). Dunand, F. 1990. Catalogue des Terres cuites gréco-romaines d’Egypte. Musée du louvre. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Paris. Şahin, M. 2001. Hellenistic braziers in the British Museum: Trade contacts between ancient Mediterranean cities. Anatolian Studies 51: 91-132. Myśliwiec, K. and Abu Senna, S. 1995. Polish-Egyptian excavations at Tell Atrib in 1991 - 1993. ‘Etudes et Travaux’ 17: 205-240.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3685)
Şahin 2001 / Hellenistic braziers in the British Museum: Trade contacts between ancient Mediterranean cities (p.120, fig. 120:Na 12.)
